docs.abstract: Should religious belief be allowed to trump public responsibility?
docs.snippet: Should religious belief be allowed to trump public responsibility?

docs.lead_paragraph: The refusal by an upstate New York town clerk to sign marriage licenses for same-sex couples, as reported on the front page of The Times last week, can be seen simply as a discordant footnote to the march of marriage equality in New York State. But seen in a broader context, it is also more than that.

docs.lead_paragraph: 1:15 P.M. (IFC) CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER (2006) A cruel emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) and his secretive wife (Gong Li, above with Mr. Chow) plot each other's annihilation: he, by destroying her sanity with a rare fungus; she, by planning a bloody coup during a festival and persuading one of her three sons (Jay Chou) to join her revolt. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that this martial arts drama from the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, set in A.D. 928, ''achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.'' She added: ''Since his debut in 1987 with 'Red Sorghum' Mr. Zhang has made more controlled films but never one that's more fun. With 'Curse of the Golden Flower' he aims for Shakespeare and winds up with Jacqueline Susann. And a good thing too.'' 6 A.M. (Oxygen) A WALK ON THE MOON (1999) Diane Lane plays Pearl Kantrowitz, a housewife who each summer totes her ironing board, children and mother-in-law to a camp in the Catskills while her husband, Marty (Liev Schreiber), stays in New York City, repairing television sets. Viggo Mortensen is the hippie salesman who turns her life upside down in 1969, as the moon walk and Woodstock loom. Writing in The Times about this romance from Tony Goldwyn, Janet Maslin said, ''Even when it turns turbulent, the film sustains its warm summer glow, and makes itself a conversation piece about the moral issues it means to raise.''
